events.target_title: Window list extension does not switch windows when clicked on touchscreen
Converting laptop to a tablet does not switch off a touchpad
"Calculator" key cannot be assigned
Hardcoded default port breaks "bookmarks" from `ssh_config`

note.body:
Hello, I can confirm this change broke my setup as soon as 1.40 reached Arch Linux repositories.

Depending on hosts, I may use the `ssh_config` to:
*  choose the right port
*  switch to the local dns when available
*  check public SSHFP on certain hosts

The port is one parameter between others and I wish I did not have to store the same information in two different places.

So, I agree with @SimonSapin.

events.target_title: Hardcoded default port breaks "bookmarks" from `ssh_config`

note.body: I confirm it, I have the problem again with gnome 3.34.0 and 1.42.0 built by Arch Linux.

events.target_title: gnome-software using 59% of memory

note.body:
Fedora 29 with gnome-software 3.30.6 consuming 40GB of ram. 40GB!!! Gnome-software has been blowing up all the way back to like Fedora 27. (Gnome-software can't update software either so maybe that is related...)

This is from a different day but it's the same pattern every time (3/14).
![Screenshot_from_2019-03-14_06-47-32](/uploads/33cfbf7dd951278b3739c2afabc937db/Screenshot_from_2019-03-14_06-47-32.png)

Seems to coincide with dnf metadata cache systemd stuff today. Happens at other times. I don't have reliable reproduction steps other than "it happens eventually" in the background with no user involvement. Usually once a week-ish (10 days) while I'm in the middle of writing a document. lol.

events.target_title: Disable on-screen keyboard when physical keyboard is available

note.body: Well to be fair, I don't disagree with him. We should have an option to straight up disable the keyboard. Like "On", "Off", "Auto" settings. It be like asking Polly the bird if he wants a cracker and then when Polly shies away from the cracker you cram the cracker in its mouth anyway anyway. We (Polly) don't want the cracker (the OSK) but it's impossible to turn it off. Like even if we had no physical keyboard what if we wanted to use a different virtual keyboard? that virtual keyboard would have to implement something to manage to disable the OSK built-in to gnome. And adding virtual keyboard detection isn't really a solution to that circumstance. Some people simply just want to turn it off. If we wanted features crammed down our throats that we don't want we would use Windows not Linux. the only reason I'm okay with this particular fix is because I have a physical keyboard so it'll disable the extraordinarily annoying gnome OSK.

events.target_title: Changing os local timezone - changes picture time

note.body:
I also have noticed a similar time zone related problem. I had a bunch of mpeg videos from an older camera. I wanted to add the date/time to them (I could pin this down based on the photos taken immediately before and after the videos in question).

First, I used ffmpeg to convert the mpegs to mp4s. Then, using exiftool, I set the CreateDate tag in each video. I'm on the west coast of Canada, which is UTC -7 hours. When I import these files into Shotwell, the times that shotwell shows for the files are 7 hours too early. E.g., a file that has a CreateDate tag of noon is interpreted by shotwell as being created at 5am. Weirdly, Shotwell is NOT doing this with other photos and videos that were created by my camera or phone.

As stated by cdpb, timezones should not affect the time a photo was taken as interpreted by shotwell.

My monitors are 110 DPI and are perfectly modern, I just don't need higher DPI.

E.g. not leaving every user with a surprise a need to figure out what to do themselves, but rather have prepare some script for painless migration or something like that.

events.target_title: Gkr-pam:  unable to locate daemon control file

note.body:
some analysis, don't know if it's correct....

My pam lightdm looks like this:
```
#%PAM-1.0
auth        include     system-login
-auth       optional    pam_gnome_keyring.so
account     include     system-login
password    include     system-login
session     include     system-login
-session    optional    pam_gnome_keyring.so auto_start
```

my pam system-login looks like this:  
```
#%PAM-1.0

auth       required   pam_tally2.so        onerr=succeed file=/var/log/tallylog
auth       required   pam_shells.so
auth       requisite  pam_nologin.so
auth       include    system-auth

account    required   pam_tally2.so 
account    required   pam_access.so
account    required   pam_nologin.so
account    include    system-auth

password   include    system-auth

session    optional   pam_loginuid.so
session    optional   pam_keyinit.so       force revoke
session    include    system-auth
session    optional   pam_motd.so          motd=/etc/motd
session    optional   pam_mail.so          dir=/var/spool/mail standard quiet
-session   optional   pam_systemd.so       debug
session    required   pam_env.so
```

From what I can tell, the variable 'XDG_RUNTIME_DIR' is only set during the **session** of 'pam_systemd.so' (system-login) which comes after:
`-auth       optional    pam_gnome_keyring.so` 

Maybe this is the reason for the error?

events.target_title: user data objects from GtkBuilder not passed to signal handlers

note.body: Has this ever been sorted out ?  I'm trying to write a tutorial on GTK and Python and the behaviour seems inconsistent and hard to understand.  Anything specified as userdata in the .glade file replaces the the widget rather than being added as an additonal argument to the handler.

events.target_title: user data objects from GtkBuilder not passed to signal handlers

note.body:
I've been "poking around" in /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/gi/overrides/Gtk.py and it seems to me that the implementation of _builder_connect_callback is wrong.  It seems that the presence of a "connect_obj" also causes the behaviour expected when the "swapped" flag is set in the glade file.  I changed gobj.connect_object(signal_name, handler, connect_obj, *args)  to
gobj.connect(signal_name, handler, connect_obj, *args) and the behaviour is now as expected (more like the C API), with the userdata specified in the glade file appearing as an extra parameter to the handler. 

I realise that changing this might break some things so what can be done to provide this behaviour ?

PeterO

Error parsing image data 'Error interpreting JPEG image file (Improper call to JPEG library in state 205)'
Add support for Python 3 asyncio event loop (PEP 3156)

note.body:
I'd like to clarify that this is not a fringe issue. To put it in perspective, asyncio has been the standard and preferred way to do event-based programming in python for years now, and the absence of an asyncio-compatible event loop means glib/gobject is isolating itself from the python community.

Nobody wants to complicate their code or mess around with awkward hacks just to get a GUI-centric toolkit to play nicely with standard coroutines. Nobody wants to learn glib's special way of doing a hundred common things that python's standard library already does just so they can avoid such hackery. After biting the bullet and trying anyway in a recent project, I found the experience to be painful and excessively time consuming, and now know that I would rather use a different GUI toolkit in future projects.

On the other hand, if this issue is fixed, glib and family would become relatively painless for python developers, and therefore more likely to be used in new projects.

events.target_title: Power save and KMS error handling fixes

note.body:
Just tested the new updates. Some interesting behaviour. 

From first boot, no external displays. Suspend resume works fine.

With external display. no longer crashes mutter. Instead on resume just presented with a blank display and backlight cycles on for a few secs, off briefly then on repeatedly. I can switch to 1st VT, then GDM starts on next "on" cycle and I can then switch to the VT that my session is running on and unlock and continue. Nothing crashed or lost. Tried switching to other VT's but nothing seemed to happen. If I disconnect external display, while hung then mutter does crash.

Return from just locking behaves the same as above, irrespective of external display. One possible difference is mousepointer visible on display, but not moveable (I assume this is only because machine hasn't actually gone into standby?). Note currently my machine is set to blank screen immediately on lock.

Have attached Journal for dual display suspend resume, not sure it's very helpful though.

events.target_title: Some bitmap fonts render spaces as unicode 0020 boxes

note.body:
I have this issue too. It seems to be some sort of incompatibility with pango and the new freetype 2.10, as I only see this problem in pango-based applications; freetype+fontconfig+cairo-only applications work.

There appears to be two ways this manifests in (assuming it's the same bug); the first is the "unicode 0020 box" - I see this with TerminusV (a variable-width version of Terminus). The second way is "disappearing" fonts; both pango-list and fc-match list/match these fonts, but all pango-based applications still refuse to render them. And as far as I can tell, they're all bitmap fonts.

Maybe something related to font fallback handling?

```sh
% FC_DEBUG=4 pango-view --font="artwiz aqui"  -q -t 'a'|grep family:
        ...
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
	family: "Verdana"(s)
	family: "Verdana"(s)
```
There doesn't appear to be a fontconfig rule that causes the switch:
```sh
...
Rule Set: /etc/fonts/conf.d/90-synthetic.conf
FcConfigSubstitute test font any slant Equal roman
FcConfigSubstitute test pattern any slant NotEqual roman
No match
FcConfigSubstitute test font any weight LessEqual medium
No match
FcConfigSubstitute donePattern has 38 elts (size 48)
	family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
        ...

FcConfigSubstitute Pattern has 38 elts (size 48)
	family: "Verdana"(s)
```
Except the omitted font data, there's no additional output between the two `FcConfigSubstitute`.

events.target_title: Some bitmap fonts render spaces as unicode 0020 boxes

note.body:
In case this helps; with *Artwiz Aqui* `.` does _not_ get substituted, while `a` does:
```sh
FC_DEBUG=4 pango-view --font="artwiz aqui"  -q -t '.'|grep family:
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)

FC_DEBUG=4 pango-view --font="artwiz aqui"  -q -t 'a'|grep family:
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "artwiz aqui"(s)
    family: "Verdana"(s)
    family: "Verdana"(s)
```

events.target_title: Some bitmap fonts render spaces as unicode 0020 boxes

note.body: This is hopefully already obvious to the devs, but for completeness: ```sh FC_DEBUG=4 pango-view --font="artwiz aqui" --markup -q -t 'a'|grep family: family: "artwiz aqui"(s) family: "artwiz aqui"(s) family: "artwiz aqui"(s) family: "artwiz aqui"(s) family: "artwiz aqui"(s) family: "artwiz aqui"(s) ``` I.e. turning off fallback "fixes" it (and renders just fine, btw).

events.target_title: Some bitmap fonts render spaces as unicode 0020 boxes

note.body: Turned out this was a freetype2 bug after all: https://savannah.nongnu.org/bugs/?56067. Fix is scheduled for the 2.10.1 release.

note.body: Will probably only be able to try out a new build next week with proper debug symbols. But I don't recall JSON-C having any options in ./configure to enable debugging symbols.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.8 builds but fails to launch: Assertion `json_object_get_type(jso) == json_type_object' failed.

note.body:
No, I didn't build a development branch of MyPaint. What I have is definitely libmypaint 1.3.0 from a tarball. Same for mypaint-brushes.

The tarballs were all taken from links provided by the BLFS handbook.

events.target_title: GIMP 2.10.8 builds but fails to launch: Assertion `json_object_get_type(jso) == json_type_object' failed.

note.body:
As mentioned, the earliest I can do a rebuild with debug symbols will be some time next week.

Until this issue gets properly sorted out, can I please request the GIMP developers to ***not*** remove the `-d` option from GIMP for the foreseeable future?

Reason being I only use GIMP to enhance and edit my photographs and append watermarks, all of which are not dependent on features and functionality provided by libmypaint and mypaint-brushes. This will at least allow me to build newer versions *and* continue working on my photos and images even with such errors.

events.target_title: Unix Line Endings
Unix Line Endings

note.body: Sometimes it's just the one or two lines that I've edited that don't register my new lines. Sometimes it's the whole file. Sorry, I'm having trouble reproducing the problem. I'm not sure when it happens. I work on network router/switch configs. Sometimes I open a file and copy it over to the right side to track the changes. Sometimes I start with a blank comparison and paste a config into both panes. I save the files and open them in notepad++.

note.body:
I'm seeing this same issue, in my case on first boot or sleep/wake, my wired connection incorrectly shows as disconnected. Restarting Gnome Shell fixes the issue, but that's a bit of a pain...

Rhythmbox should show confirmation dialog before deleting a playlist

note.body:
I completely agree there should be a prompt. Either add a prompt or send the old playlist to the trashcan folder. 

Now there is a workaround. If you accidentally delete the playlist by clicking the '-' button, DONT close the rhythmbox app. If you do its gone. 
 
As soon as you click the '-' button, 

1. Open a command or terminal shell and Go to the $HOME/.local/share/rhythmbox directory
2. run the command $ cp playlists.xml to playlistSave.xml
3. then close rhythmbox  
4. Then run the command $cp playlistSave.xml to playlists.xml 
5. and re-open Rhythmbox. and your back to where you were. 

This is how you can keep a backup of your playlists. The XML file is editable (its a text file) so if you move your music library or files you can mass edit the file without having to rebuild your playlists.

note.body: @tpopela @dwmw2 any news about this ? Is there anything I can do to help the review ? Thanks

events.target_title: ntlm: fix ntlmv2 authentication

note.body:
Some additional details:

This MR add a new "unknown" field, but it's seems to be just padding at the end of the blob (according to the old documentation from Eric Glass). 
I added this to get closer to the (working) response sent using manual curl requests. However, in the end this was not necessary for me the have auth working, so I am fine with removing this part.

If I remove the extra padding, the patch can become a one liner, only fixing the NTLMSSP_NEGOTIATE_EXTENDED_SESSIONSECURITY bit at line 964. Basically the bit will be set iif it was set in the initial query, which is I think the correct behavior. I can try to have a look at the MS spec and check if they are in line with this.

events.target_title: Touch screen
GtkFileChooserDialog shows non-existent directories
Distracting "SyncTeX Error" message even with files not created with TeX

note.body:
> A side effect of updating to the latest synctex, it is chattier than it used to be.

Consider the following scenario:

1. Open a new terminal.
1. Launch evince on a PDF in the background.
1. Start `vim` to edit a document in the foreground.
1. Open a second terminal.
1. In the second Terminal, overwrite the PDF.

This will cause the error message to appear in `vim`, forcing the user to refresh the console.

One of the reasons evince is amazing is because it reloads PDFs that have been modified. I use this all the time when editing and generating PDF documents via ConTeXt (a TeX typesetting engine).

I understand that there are already plans in place to address the issue and am raising this as a use case that might not have been considered.

An obvious work-around is to create a `bash` alias that redirects standard output and standard error to `/dev/null` when running `evince` from the command line.

events.target_title: Missing accelerator on "Export Image as JPEG" dialog

note.body:
I use accelerator keys a lot, especially when exporting. For example, to scale an image:

1. Load an image
1. `Alt+i`, `s`, `1024`, `Alt+s`
1. `Ctrl+Shift+e`
1. Type in a filename.
1. `Alt+e` to export.
1. `Alt+e` to export again.

The second `Alt+e` no longer works, but it did in previous versions.

```
$ gimp --version
GNU Image Manipulation Program version 2.10.10
```

events.target_title: Some widgets don't draw their initial focus indicator
Some widgets don't draw their initial focus indicator

note.body:
I wonder if a compromise could be reached here. Windows has a setting to enable/disable this, very useful for data entry type of users/applications.

I am not sure a setting will be implemented on GTK since something like `gtk-visible-focus` is gone. Probably drawing focus indicator after the user used TAB for keyboard navigation (not any keyboard interaction) and this being sticky for all the application process life, instead of per window.

Note: Firefox and Chromium always draw the focus indicator on combo boxes, even with no keyboard interaction (Firefox do it for other input controls like radio buttons too). I think Chromium does it only for `select` HTML elements because it is too common to use arrow keys or press the first letter of an option for selection, something not frequently done with radio buttons or check boxes

events.target_title: Trying to compile on Xubuntu

note.body:
`apt build-dep gedit` did not go far. Using gedit-3.30.2. This is the same version defaulted for Ubuntu 18.10. pkg-config is looking in, for example, /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/pkgconfig/ for a .pc file for each of the packages in the list it can not find. The following provides the .pc files and very likely other files such as headers required by gedit. apt install libxml2-dev
apt install libgtk-3-dev
apt install libgtksourceview-3.0-dev
apt install libpeas-dev
apt install libxml2-utils
apt install itstool
There may be a few other packages needed I do not remember at the moment, but they should be easy to find. Compile ended with Configuration: Source code location: . Compiler: gcc Spell Plugin enabled: no Gvfs metadata enabled: yes Deprecations enabled: GObject Introspection: yes GDK Backend: x11 Python support: no Vala support: no These may also come in handy.
./configure --disable-spell
apt-cache search item
dpkg -l "\*item\*" | grep ii
https://packages.ubuntu.com/search

events.target_title: jhbuild build gedit gives gtksourceview-3.0 required but 4.0.4 in checkout

note.body:
Did the following to obtain successful compile.

jhbuild uninstall gtksourceview

rm -rf ~/jhbuild/checkout/gtksourceview/

Identified a recent 3.# branch >= 3.22.0 at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtksourceview/branches.

Added the file ~/.config/jhbuildrc.

Added the following line in ~/.config/jhbuildrc. 'gnome-3-24' is the branch identifier.

branches['gtksourceview'] = (None, 'gnome-3-24')

jhbuild build gtksourceview

jhbuild build gedit

Obtained successful compile.

Tried gedit 3.32 using the corresponding line in ~/.config/jhbuildrc. Obtained autogen.sh missing error.

Reinstalled gedit 3.30 with successful compile.

Renamed Xubuntu default /usr/bin/gedit to /usr/bin/ngedit. This was required to keep 'jhbuild run gedit' from using /usr/bin/gedit. Also if the original, renamed gedit is open on 'jhbuild run gedit', the currently opened gedit will be connected to without opening the jhbuild gedit.

events.target_title: Painting on indexed images by index

note.body:
.. Wouldn't that approach (paint indexes directly rather than converting from RGBA) only work for *binary* rendering (eg. Pencil on 100% opacity Normal Mode; or filling a selection mask that has no antialiasing)?

It seems to me that a general solution needs to instead provide a 'conversion override' value to the RGBA->paletted conversion.
If the assignment of indexed colors isn't actually 'random', but just picks the first color that matches, then that override could be in the form of an integer pair ('*whenever you would select colormap index X, select Y instead*').

Well.. I'm speculating a bit here, perhaps wrongly. I just want to be sure that the current "indexpainting" (paint+layer modes, lowered opacity, nonbinary selection mask, smooth brushes etc on an indexed image) functionality won't be impaired in any way by the fix for this issue.

I suppose there is also a secondary issue where you paint a correct index, then change color, and painting at very low opacity on this 'correct index' pixel makes it become an 'incorrect index' pixel, with no visual change. Because there is no data on what is a 'correct index' for that color being provided any longer. That particular issue seems largely insoluble.

events.target_title: Painting on indexed images by index
Painting on indexed images by index

note.body:
@Nyerguds Since you'd have to prevent desync, what about 4 bits of data : [direct color, image id, image colormap version, index]

Image colormap version would be a number stored also on any given indexed image, it would be incremented each time that the colormap changes. So combining it with image id creates a sort of UUID for a colormap.

If the image colormap version currently assigned to an image is newer than the color-selector one, then fallback can be as follows:
* if there is still a color at that index, and its RGB values match, assume this index is still correct (and update the color-selector's ICV)
* If there is not a color at that index, or its RGB values do not match, guess an index by searching the palette for the exact color values.

events.target_title: Failure to detect libmypaint on Arch Linux
Painting on indexed images counter-intuitive

note.body:
Jehan, a few comments on the work you have done here and in later commits to improve color selection on indexed images:

The basic interaction is good; click, or the arrow keys allow to immediately move through colors, although one must press Space to select them. Considering the way other color selectors behave, it might be better to select a color as soon as its pane receives keyboard focus.  Doubleclick to edit, OK.

I find it much less confusing than 2.10; mainly because I usually have the palette tab up, and this palette could be a plausible-but-wrong palette -- about the right size, and similar but not identical colors, meaning every choice I'd make from the palette would not paint as I expected. The 'out-of-gamut' detection did eventually alert me to the nature of this problem.

Is there a keyboard accessible way to perform the other 2 common actions -- Edit and Add Current? 
Since the three common actions can be sequenced to create an action which can be summarized as 'Edit a duplicate of current colormap color' -- an extremely common way of working on indexed palettes -- it would be nice to be able to perform all three of those component actions (select, add, edit) quickly. 
AFAICS there are 2 ways to activate Edit with mouse (dclick and click on button), and 1 way to activate Add Current with mouse (click on button).

.. 
The "next/prev color from swatch" actions don't work in this dialog, which is understandable but kind of weird (since their action is to select through colormap entries if the current image has a colormap)

..

Sometimes the user may actually want to select an arbitrary color without adding to palette. This is relevant when using paint modes other than Normal. I realize this is currently *possible* (go to a Colors dockable rather than this popup), but it would be nice to have a way to escape more quickly -- a kind of one off action 'just let me pick a color, I know I'm on an indexed image'

..

Being able to just immediately edit the current colormap color (skip the initial selector) would be REALLY useful, although perhaps out of the scope of the selector?
Currently you have to either use your selector and doubleclick a particular swatch, or .. use the colormap editor and doubleclick a particular swatch. They're not too slow, but they're awkward because you're not just clicking on the color you can see in-context in the image.


..

It might be good to formalize color duplication (effectively: select colormap entry, then 'add current color') into another discrete action, in order to better control the location of the duplicate. My experience with indexed images suggests that the usual 'correct location' for a duplicate in an ordered palette is immediately after or before the original color, rather than at the end (though I understand that insertion at the end is easier, as it avoids the need to modify image pixels -> messing with undo)

..

Ok, most serious problem for last. The semantics of the Cancel button are weird.
A user could reasonably say that it is broken. 

That is because it reverts the 'current selected color', but does not revert the other undo steps on the image itself. So you edit some colors, decide they were bad edits, Cancel and your edits are *not* canceled.
I understand why this is happening but I think it's also obvious why this would confuse the user (OK/Cancel dialogs generally imply some kind of transaction (in the database sense), with Cancel being expected to roll back the entire transaction). If editing colors should stay (IMO it should), then there needs to be some kind of better communication of what will happen when Cancel is pressed.

events.target_title: Failure to detect libmypaint on Arch Linux

note.body:
@Jehan 
Seems this is a [backport](https://git.archlinux.org/svntogit/packages.git/tree/trunk/versioning.patch?h=packages/libmypaint) of a [upstream change](https://github.com/mypaint/libmypaint/pull/94) (in the libmypaint-2.0 era) which was prompted by some members of the GIMP team complaining about non-obvious API breakage. IOW: deliberately applying the same packaging rules chosen by libmypaint-2.x to libmypaint 1.x.

The packager responsible (Levente Polyak) is also co-maintainer on the GIMP package and sole maintainer on the mypaint-brushes package (the only two packages in standard Arch repositories which rely on mypaint). GIMP package also explicitly patches configure.ac on the basis of libmypaint version, so there is no way he is not aware of this problem.

BTW, have you read [my comments](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/2938#note_494091) on the current indexed color selection interface? I think I didn't do the right thing (@ mention) to get you notified.

events.target_title: Failure to detect libmypaint on Arch Linux

note.body:
I'm simply clarifying the history of the situation for third parties, much as you did in your previous comment. I don't expect anybody on the GIMP project to do anything about it.

I can see why you would say I was mixing topics, but I had to figure out what the system was actually doing somehow. You seem to have more or less confirmed that this particular system sends notifications even if you are not explicitly @ mentioned. That's fine, I'm not trying to rush your response (or even non-response), I just want to have some clue whether I'm using the system correctly.

events.target_title: Screen tearing in full screen mode

note.body:
Typically several pages. Scrolling a few image heavy pages results in obvious tearing.

This only happens if Evince is run in full screen mode. It does not occur if you have a normal window. 

As I understand it, Gnome unredirects all full screen windows. This is great for some apps -- games for e.g. But it does not work for Evince. I have been using the Disable Unredirect Extension to fix this since I do not game. 

A Public Domain sample comic is available from archive.org at this link:
https://archive.org/download/WonderBoy17/Wonder_Boy_017_Ajax_1955-May_36p_c2c_Snardermann.cbz

With regard to Libreoffice, it does not seem to have this problem -- at least not with text files. I don't have any graphics heavy documents that it would open to try.

events.target_title: adding public ical calendar ask for login and password

note.body:
Yep, same for me, too. In `src/gcal-source-dialog.c`, `e_webdav_discover_sources` errors out; `e_webdav_discover_sources_finish` returns false in `discover_sources_cb`. The error code is 405, and the message is 

```
(gnome-calendar:18920): GcalSourceDialog-DEBUG: 15:07:49.278: [source-dialog] error-message: Failed to get properties: HTTP error code 405 (Method Not Allowed): The server responded with an HTML page, which can mean there’s an error on the server or with the client request. The used URI was: https://calendar.google.com/calendar/ical/7dposggmqi4bbleoii3an2cphg%40group.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics
```

However, I can access this URL using my browser as well as curl, which happily reports a HTTP 200 and a content-type of "text/calendar".

After looking at the traffic with wireshark, it turns out that gnome-calendar (i.e. evolution-data-server) uses a `PROPFIND` HTTP method to request data from Google, which returns the 405. This can be replicated using `curl -XPROPFIND -I https://calendar.google.com/calendar/ical/fr.french%23holiday%40group.v.calendar.google.com/public/basic.ics`. I'm not quite sure how to fix that - would it be a bug in evolution-data-server? Because for now I think it does make sense to try again with credentials, since we just run into the default error handling...

note.body:
>  Did you move your library around?

Not recently. I've been using the same directory structure for years.

I've been using the same routine for years as well:
1. Move photo's to the desired locations myself
1. Disconnect camera
1. Do some renaming if necessary
1. Run Shotwell...

Except 2 days ago -- shortly before submitting the bug report -- I launched Shotwell first instead of last. So, one could argue that I have moved parts of my library around (i.e. from camera to photo directory, and finally from one directory name to another).

Since 2 days ago, Shotwell wants to extract its own JPEG-file from each RAW-file. The behavior is unnecessary, if only because because my camera already develops a separate JPEG-file for each RAW that it captures.

The additional JPEG-files that appeared first, have originated from the latest imported batch 2 days ago. I noticed it because some of these JPEG-files have also appeared as a duplicate inside Shotwell, while only a single photo appeared for each RAW + JPEG-pair from my camera.


> Please try with 0.30.1 from https://launchpad.net/\~yg-jensge/+archive/ubuntu/shotwell

Installed & tested:
1. This version did not start processing RAW-files immediately.
1. I was able to re-import my latest batch of photo's and re-enable monitoring.
1. Shortly after this, unfortunately, additional image files started appearing again...
1. After closing Shotwell, the creation of additional image files went on regardless. Shotwell seemed active in the background (not sure if it was the same instance or a different one). The instance appeared to respawn after having been stopped using the process monitor (C S). Terminating (C K) worked as expected.

events.target_title: automatic creation of additional images files -- embedded JPEG extracted from DNG

note.body: The other tickets look familiar.

events.target_title: automatic creation of additional images files -- embedded JPEG extracted from DNG

note.body:
Update:
I've decided to backup `photo.db` and see if I can revert whatever it was that caused Shotwell to behave differently now.

First purged all Shotwell and Embedded references in PhotoTable:
> 1. `update PhotoTable`
> 1. `set developer = "CAMERA", develop_shotwell_id = -1, develop_embedded_id = -1`
> 1. `where develop_shotwell_id > -1 OR developer not like "CAMERA";`

Next deleted all orphaned records in BackingPhotoTable:
> 1. `delete from BackingPhotoTable`
> 1. `where id not in (`
> 1. `  select p.develop_camera_id`
> 1. `  from PhotoTable p`
> 1. `  where p.develop_camera_id > -1`
> 1. `);`

Next remove all additional images files and start a watcher:
> 1. `% find ~/Foto\'s/* -type f -regextype posix-extended -iregex ".+_(DNG|CR2)_(embedded|shotwell)(|_[0-9])\.jpg$" -delete`
> 1. `% watch -n 30 "find ~/Foto\'s/* -type f -regextype posix-extended -iregex '.+_(DNG|CR2)_(embedded|shotwell)(|_[0-9])\.jpg$' | wc -l"`

It returned 0 as expected, initially, but within minutes the counter had increased to 70...

So, terminated Shotwell and returned to investigating `photo.db` again...

70 records had been updated with Shotwell-developer and ditto records created in BackingPhotoTable:
> 1. `select p.id, p.filename, p2.filepath, p.metadata_dirty, p.developer, p.develop_shotwell_id, p.develop_camera_id, p.develop_embedded_id`
> 1. `from PhotoTable p`
> 1. `left join BackingPhotoTable p2`
> 1. `on p2.id = p.develop_shotwell_id`
> 1. `where p2.filepath like "%embedded%.jpg" or p2.filepath like "%shotwell%.jpg";`

**TL;DR**
It appears that Shotwell decides that *it* should be the developer, despite that Camera is configured as the preferred developer and in spite of the fact that the records where updated for Camera-developer.
